questions.question: 1. What happens to the average output voltage of a controlled bridge rectifier as the firing angle increases?

explanations.b: Explanation 2: As the firing angle increases, the conduction period decreases, reducing the average output voltage.

questions.question: 2. Which of the following methods can be used to control the output voltage of a controlled bridge rectifier?

answers.a: Only by changing the amplitude of the input AC voltage
answers.b: Changing the frequency of the input AC voltage
answers.c: Only by controlling the firing angle of the SCR
answers.d: By changing the amplitude of the input AC voltage and/or firing angle

explanations.d: Explanation 4: The output voltage of a controlled bridge rectifier can be controlled by adjusting the input AC voltage amplitude and/or the firing angle of the SCR.

questions.question: 3. What is the main advantage of a controlled bridge rectifier over an uncontrolled bridge rectifier?

explanations.d: Explanation 4: A controlled bridge rectifier allows precise control of the output voltage and power by adjusting the firing angle of the thyristors, which is not the case in uncontrolled rectifier.

questions.question: 4. What happens to the source current waveform shape when a resistive load is replaced by a highly inductive load?

explanations.d: Explanation 4: Highly inductive loads will not allow sudden change in the current while the current in resistive load follow the voltage.

questions.question: 5. What happens when two thyristor of same leg starts conducting?

answers.b: The output load current starts to freewheel.
answers.c: Source current is same as load current.
answers.d: Load voltage is same as the source voltage.

explanations.a: Explanation 1: If both thyristors in the same leg of a bridge rectifier conduct simultaneously, it creates a direct short circuit across the input voltage source.
